question: The attache case has been empty for three years, but it makes him safe to think there's a machine pistol in it. He likes to hear stories about Nam. I tell him I can't; they're not cleared. The truth is he wouldn't understand. There's no way I can tell them... what really happened over there. There was only one part that mattered -- for me, anyway. I don't even know if I remember all of it. I can't remember how it ended, exactly -- because when it ended I was insane. But I know how it started for me -- I was on R. and R. in Saigon; my first time south of the DMZ in three months. I wasn't sure, but I thought this guy was following me.
answer: How about a drink ?

question: Sure, thanks.
answer: Winning the war by yourself.

question: Part.
answer: Which part is that ?

question: My part.
answer: That's good gin.

question: I'm sure it is, but I had hepatitis.
answer: Delta ?

question: No.
answer: North ?

question: Yeah. Way north.
answer: What unit were you with ?

question: None.
answer: Rangers, eh?

question: Sort of.
answer: Were you Longe Range Recon --

question: No -- I worked too far north for
answer: That's quite an array of ribbons...

question: Let's talk about you.
answer: I was an FO for the 25th.

question: Tracks ?
answer: Yeah.

question: Fat. That's real fat.
answer: Sometimes.

question: At least you always have enough water. How many gallons does each one of those damn things carry ?
answer: Thirty -- sometimes fifty.

question: You know, I can remember once, getting back below the DMZ -- and the first Americans we ran into were a track squadron. I just couldn't believe how much water they had. We'd been chewing bamboo shoots for almost a week, and before that, for two weeks, we'd been drinking anything -- rain water, river shit, stuff right out of the paddies. And there were these guys standing by their trucks spilling water all over. I could've killed them. I swear to God I would have, too, if ...
answer: I didn't know we had units up there in North Vietnam.

question: We do.
answer: How long were you up there ?

question: A long time.
answer: A year ? Waiter another beer.

question: They took me to some place outside Nha Trang... Intelligence Headquarters for all operations in South East Asia. I'd worked for Intelligence before -- Captain B.L. Willard, G-4 Headquarters, reporting as ordered, sir.
answer: Okay, Willard, sit down. Have you ever seen this officer before, Captain Willard ?

question: No, sir.
answer: This gentleman or myself ?

question: No, sir.
answer: I believe on your last job you executed a tax collector in Kontum, is that right ?

question: We communicate with the base infrequently. What they call for are air strikes, immediate -- always at night. And we don't know what or who the air strikes are called on.
answer: Who ?

question: You see, no one has really gone into this area and come back alive.
answer: Why me ?

question: Walter Kurtz, Lieutenant Colonel, Special Forces. We understand you knew him.
answer: Yeah.

question: Anyone got a cigarette. I thought he was a lame.
answer: A lame ?

question: This is years ago, before he joined Special Forces, I guess. We had an argument.
answer: About what ?

question: I don't know. He was a lame, that's all.
answer: But why ?

question: He couldn't get through a sentence without all these big words; about why we kill.
answer: Well, he's killing now.

question: The point is that Kurtz or somebody attacked a South Vietnamese Ranger Platoon three days ago. Last week a Recon helicopter was lost in the area -- another took heavy damage -- direct fire from their base camp.
answer: Our Recon flight ?

question: Ours.
answer: Touchy.

question: You can see, of course, the implications, if any of this -- even rumours leaked out.
answer: You want me to clean it up -- simple and quiet.

question: Exactly -- you'll go up the Nung River in a Navy P.B.R. -- appear at Nu Mung Ba as if by accident, re-establish your acquintance with Colonel Kurtz, find out what's happened -- and why. Then terminate his command.
answer: Terminate ?

question: Terminate with extreme prejudice.
answer: I met the P.B.R. crew; they were pretty much all kids, except for Phillips, the Chief -- Gunner's Mate Third Class L. Johnson -- Lance Johnson; Gunner's Mate Third Class J. Hicks -- The Chef -- Radio Operator Second Class T. Miller; they called him Mr. Clean. Chief, try to keep out of where we're going -- Why we're goin' and what's gonna be the big surprise.

question: I met the P.B.R. crew; they were pretty much all kids, except for Phillips, the Chief -- Gunner's Mate Third Class L. Johnson -- Lance Johnson; Gunner's Mate Third Class J. Hicks -- The Chef -- Radio Operator Second Class T. Miller; they called him Mr. Clean. Chief, try to keep out of where we're going -- Why we're goin' and what's gonna be the big surprise.
answer: All right with me, I used to drive a taxi.

question: Let's go.
answer: The Delta closes off to us about ten miles out of Hau Fat. We'll be able to pick up some supplies -- bit I think there are only two points we can draw enough water to get into the Nung River. It's all Charlie's turf from there on out.

question: We're gonna have some help to get in the river. You know these waters, Chief ?
answer: 'Bout six months ago I took a man up to Lo Mung Bridge. He was regular Army too. Shot himself in the head. I brought his body back down.

question: Shot himself. What for ?
answer: Beats me -- the sun was too much for him, or the mud. Who knows ?

question: I don't know anything about these papers, sir.
answer: They're in order -- it's perfectly clean -- just check with ComSec- Intel like I said.

question: Well, you know I don't have the priority to do that, sir. It says here not to contact Com-Sec- Int. Who's your commanding officer ?
answer: Right now -- I am.

question: Well who the hell verifies that ?
answer: I do.

question: The show --
answer: What show ?

question: Big show in the parade grounds this noon -- some boss stuff --
answer: This -- Bob Hope or the like --

question: Yeah -- you can really get hung up on them like the cat in the Delta.
answer: What cat ?

question: One that went up for murder -- he was an Army Sergeant.
answer: I never heard about that.

question: Yeah -- he really dug his Playboy mag, man -- I mean like he was there when it arrived -- He just knew.
answer: So what happened ?

question: He was working A.R.V.N. patrols and had one a them little cocky gook asshole Lieutenants -- anyhow, the Lieutenant took his new Playboy one day, sat on the end of the dock, and wouldn't give it back.
answer: Yeah -- typical A.R.V.N.

question: Two days out of Hau Fat, there was nothing but us and the coastline. I felt like I had set off for the center of the earth...
answer: Smoke !

question: Where ? Black smoke ... secondary burning.
answer: Yeah -- fishing village -- helicopters over there. Hueys, lots of 'em.

question: Yeah -- Na Trang told me to expect you -- we'll see what we can do. Just stay out of my way till this is done, Captain. Six a spades -- eight a hearts -- Isn't one worth a Jack in this whole place. What ? Here. You sure? What's your name, sailor ?
answer: Gunner's Mate, Third Class -- L. Johnson, sir.

question: Lance Johnson? The surfer?
answer: That's right, sir.

question: It's an honor to meet you Lance. I've admired your nose-riding for years -- I like your cutback, too. I think you have the best cutback there is.
answer: Thank you, sir.

question: That's terrible -- we'll change that -- I'd like to see you work -- I've always liked your cutback; got a hell of a left turn, too. Why the hell you wanna go up to Nu Mung Ba for?
answer: I got bored in Saigon.

question: What's the furthest you been in?
answer: Haiphong.

question: Haiphong? Shit, you jump in ?
answer: No. Walked.

question: What'd you do for supplies?
answer: Mercenaries -- agents, traitors -- they put out caches.

question: Can you trust them?
answer: No. They put out two or three for every one I needed. When you get to the one you'll use, you just stake it out. If something feels wrong, you just pass it up. On one mission, I had to pass up three and ended up living on rats and chocolate bars.

question: Nu Mung Ba. Last I heard, Walter Kurtz commanded a Green Beret detachment at Nu Mung Ba.
answer: When did you hear?

question: 'Bout a year ago? Is Kurtz still alive?
answer: Who knows.

question: Seems to me he got himself fragged. i heard some grunt rolled a grenade in his tent. Maybe a rumor. Helluva man -- remarkable officer. Walter Kurtz woulda been a General some day. General of the Army. Shit, Head of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Did you knew Kurtz?
answer: I met him.

question: Don't you agree?
answer: He musta changed ! I got to get into the Nung River, here or here.

question: That village you're pointing at is kinda hairy.
answer: Hairy ?

question: I mean it's hairy -- they got some pretty heavy ordnance, boy -- I've lost a few recon ships in there now and again.
answer: So? I heard you had a good bunch of killers here.

question: And I don't intend to get some of them chewed up just to get your tub put in the mouth of the goddman Nung River. You say you don't know Kurtz?
answer: I met him.

question: You talk like him. I don't mind taking casualties, Captain, but I like to keep my ratio ten to one in this unit -- ten Cong to one.
answer: You'll find enough Cong up there.

question: Why the hell didn't you tell me about that place -- a good left. There aren't any good left slides in this whole, shitty country. It's all goddamn beach break.
answer: It's hairy ,though. That's where we lost McDonnel -- they shot the hell out of us. It's Charlie's point.

question: How big it is?
answer: Six to eight feet.

question: Yeah. Classical stuff -- scares the hell out of the slopes -- the boys love it.
answer: Eagle Thrust formation target 2800 yards -- begin psch-war operations.

question: Big Duke Six to Hell's Angels Four -- bring it in on along tree line and huts.
answer: Hell's Angels Four to Big Duke Six -- we'll need green smoke -- suggest you have the FAC mark it.

question: It'll get here, soldier. Change.
answer: Wh -- what?

question: Change -- get out there -- I want'a see if it's ridable -- change.
answer: It's still pretty hairy, sir.

question: You want'a surf, soldier? That's good, boy, because it's either surf or fight. I'm gonna cover for 'em -- that's all. You think that section on the point is ridable, Lance?
answer: I think we ought to wait for the tide to come in.

question: Doesn't happen for six hours. The tide -- doesn't come in for six hours. They far enough?
answer: Sure -- fine --

question: That's far enough -- pick one up and come on in --
answer: Maybe he'll get tubed.

question: Are you finished surfing?
answer: Yeah... thanks.

question: Want to say goodbye to the Colonel?
answer: Nah.

question: Then let's get the hell out of here.
answer: No -- no, Captain.

question: Which one's the Colonel's?
answer: The Yater -- the clear one with the thin stringer.

question: Take one a mine --
answer: You hear it again?

question: No -- I don't think so. But it'll be back. They were circling. It'll be back.
answer: You think he'd of shot us?

question: When?
answer: Any time -- us -- Americans.

question: I don't think hed of shot us on the beach but -- he'd of shot us if he saw me taking the board --
answer: A Yater spoon is hard to get -- especially here.

question: I'll go with him -- I wanta get my feet on solid land once in awhile -- Chef.
answer: Yes, sir --

question: Why they call you that?
answer: Call me what, sir?

question: Chef -- is that 'cause you like mangoes an' stuff?
answer: No, sir -- I'm a real chef, sir -- I'm a sauciere --

question: A sauciere --
answer: That's right, sir -- I come from New Orleans -- I was raised to be a sauciere.. a great sauciere. We specialize in sauces; my whole family. It's what we do. I was supposed to go to Paris and study at the Escoffier School; I was saving the money. They called me for my physical so I figured the Navy had better food.

question: What are you doing out here?
answer: Cook school -- that did it.

question: How?
answer: They lined us all up in front of a hundred yards of prime rib -- magnificent meat, beautifully marbled.. Then they started throwing it in these big cauldrons, all of it -- boiling. I looked in, an' it was turning gray. I couldn't stand it. I went into radio school.

question: -- quiet -- There...
answer: It's a motherfucking tiger -- goddamn... Goddamn -- Jesus Christ tiger -- motherfucking tiger -- ohhhhhhhhh -- Ohhhh -- tiger ! Oh goddamn ! It's a tiger ! Jesus Christ ! Goddamn, a tiger ! Ohhhhhhhh.

question: The dossier of A Dtachment contained letters from the families and wives of Kurtz' men There were letters from Kurtz' wife as well. Dearest Walt -- I have to confess something. I know how you feel about this, but I had to ask Bob to find out what he could -- I just couldn't stand it anymore, not knowing where you are, whether you're alive or dead. I'm sorry Walt, I'm sorry I said that. Bob didn't tell me anything -- he said he couldn't -- I can't stand it anymore, Walt -- I just can't stand it. I have to take the kids to school every morning now -- carpools just never work out. Soldier -- where's your C.O.?
answer: Stepped on a booby trap, sir -- got blown all to hell --

question: Well , who's in command here?
answer: I don't know -- don't have any idea -- I'm just the night man --

question: You came in on that boat, didn't you?
answer: Yeah --

question: Where are you headed?
answer: What's it matter? Get to the point.

question: Look -- you know the girls -- Thta's Terri -- she was playmate of --
answer: Yeah, I caught your show at Hau Fat.

question: Oh -- I see -- Well, girls, this is Captain -- eh --
answer: Captain Willard -- go ahead.

question: Look -- we got in a little trouble -- they rudely took our helicopter for MedEvac work on this -- uh Operation Brute Force -- They just brought it back this morning.
answer: Yeah.

question: Well I mean like they also took our fuel -- We've been here two days.
answer: Dreadful.

question: Look -- the girls could get killed -- we're not supposed to be this close combat, I mean real combat.
answer: Well --

question: We could use some fuel -- just a half drum -- just enough to get us out a here.
answer: We need all our fuel.

question: But, Captain, think what these girls have done for the boys -- think of how they've risked -- Look -- you know who that is, Captain -- you know what she's saying -- you'll never see stuff that good outside of a magazine for the rest of your life.
answer: I'm not that fond of blondes -- maybe I like brunettes --

question: Take your pick -- they all like you -- I can tell --
answer: I like all of them --

question: Good -- like I said, take your pick.
answer: I said I like all of them.

question: Now just a second -- I'm doing you a favor, buddy -- what're you trying to pull?
answer: We need all our fuel anyway.

question: Wait -- wait -- don't get up tight -- what I meant was we'd need a whole drum for that --
answer: Sit down -- we'll talk about it.

question: What's there to talk about -- this whole thing disgusts me.
answer: My men --

question: What !
answer: That's what there is to talk about -- my man -- I take a good care of my men --

question: You're out of your skull --
answer: We have a lot of pride in our unit --

question: How far do you think you can push -- what kind of people do you think --
answer: Esprit de corps --

question: No -- absolutely not --
answer: One for all -- all for one --

question: You can keep your fucking fuel --
answer: You make some of your closest friends in the army -- war has a way of bringing men together.

question: Get out --
answer: Men of all races -- nationalities --

question: Two drums -- Two whole drums --
answer: We can use some fifty caliber and a 16 too --

question: I don't know what you're talking about -- Get fucked --
answer: I will -- I assure you that -- You got a fifty on that H-34 -- leave the ammo in boxes -- I'll get my men to bring the first drum with 'em -- Have the girls freshen up a bit -- comb their hair -- put on something -- you know what I mean --

question: Captain Willard?
answer: That's me.

question: Captain Willard -- we got these from Nha Thrang two days ago -- they expected you here then -- You don't know how happy that makes me, sir.
answer: Why?

question: Now I can get out a here -- if I can find a way out.
answer: We'll be needing some supplies and fuel -- do you know anybody who can give me a hand?

question: I'd just clear out as soon as I could if I were you, sir. They're gonna start working on the bridge with torches again. Charlie will start throwing it in hard --
answer: What is this bridge?

question: You came right to it, son of a bitch --
answer: Son of a bitch, sir. Where's your chief supply officer?

question: Beverly Hills --
answer: What?

question: Straight up the road -- a concrete bunker -- Beverly Hills -- where else you think he'd be?
answer: C'mon --

question: They were tryin' to cut through the wire -- I got 'em all I think. He's trying to call his friends -- send up a flare. Wake up the Roach.
answer: Yeah, man.

question: Hear him?
answer: Sure , yeah.

question: You need a flare --
answer: No, its cool. He's close -- real close. Muhhh Fuhhh ...

question: Hey, buddy, that boat still runs, eh?
answer: Yeah, it still runs.

question: Do me a favor buddy, please.
answer: What is it?

question: Send these out when you get back to the world. It's to everyone I really knew -- the first girl I screwed -- my brother -- best friend -- I wanted to tell 'em how much I enjoyed knowing 'em -- it's been a great twenty years. I gotta let 'em know.
answer: What're you askin' me for -- put 'em in the first helicopter comes in tomorrow.

question: Nobody comes in here. The N.V.A. 312th -- over there the 307th -- on that hill we counted fourteen different guns in one minute -- they got rockets mortars, snipers in those trees, there's a million of those shitty little bastards out there -- we're all gonna die. I'm gonna be dead. You got a chance in that boat -- by morning you could be five miles down the river.
answer: We ain't goin' down the river. What's up river from here anyhow --

question: Spooky.
answer: Charlie?

question: Wow, you must a found the C.O., eh?
answer: We found some bodies -- let's get out a here.

question: I can't see a fucking thing. We hit a big enough one this hull will shatter like a Corvette. Fucking plastic boat.
answer: What about ducking into one of those tributaries till this river slows down?

question: Who knows what's up there?
answer: Can't be any worse than this. What do you think?

question: I think this river wants to take us home fast. I'm practically goin' in reverse.
answer: Well, get in there.

question: This whole area is lousy with V.C. -- We don't stand a chance. Lemme turn around and we'll be in Hau Fat in six minutes.
answer: Get in there !

question: This is my crew and my fucking boat, and I'm the responsible party.
answer: Get in there now or I'll bury you in this river.

question: What do you see?
answer: I don't know.

question: Keep cutting.
answer: I know it sounds stupid, but I feel like the goddamn jungle's watching us.

question: Probably is.
answer: Whatdoya think it thinks.

question: Throw me that ordnance. Give me some kind a field a fire --
answer: We're through. Oh, God --

question: Bring that bow ordnance into those trees.
answer: There's some bad holes, man, and the cracks -- water's coming through the cracks. Food's shot to hell.

question: How much is left?
answer: Less than half -- sure is a mess down there.

question: And the grass?
answer: Still got a lot of that stuff from Nha Trang. But we're running low on the other.

question: Hey. That's a light down there --
answer: Yeah, it is.

question: Maybe you shouldn't say we're Americans?
answer: Chef, try your French.

question: Nous sommes Americains -- Nous ne voulon pas vous agresser.
answer: French Nationals -- they may not be too friendly, though.

question: Fifty calibers, eh, Captain --
answer: As I said, we can pay you in gold.

question: Entirely unnecessary, Captain. We share a common enemy -- you are our guests. I am Gaston de marais -- this is my family's plantation. It has been such for 121 years. It will be such after I die. This is my son, Philippe -- he has fought in Algeria and held the rank of Captain. And Henry LeFevre -- a sergeant; he was at Dien Bien Phu. My personal servant, Tran Van Kac --- My youngest son -- Christian -- Christian's wife -- Ann-Marie -- And my youngest daughter -- Claudine.
answer: American weapons?

question: Chief. Come with us.
answer: A suitable accomodation for your men, captain -- you will, of course, be quartered with us --

question: Go ahead --
answer: Captain, this way. Magnificent, eh, Captain? It is very good -- there is no current -- It is very good. I have never seen one like it in all Indochina. I was in Paris when it arrived -- do you know what might have caused --

question: Looks like a two thousand pound to me. Yeah, a two thousand pound bomb.
answer: No, I've seen those in Normandy. This is much better. My country -- my country could never originate this. Magnificent.

question: I would like to know more about the .. uh, plaque...
answer: Attacks repulsed, as I was saying. This is only for this war, Captain. Viet Cong -- 54; North Vietnamese regular forces -- 15; South Vietnamese -- 28 -- regular forces and otherwise. Americain -- 6. Of course, they were, perhaps, mistakes, Captain.

question: Of course. I -- Once we make our repairs, we could send word, we could have you evacuated from here.
answer: Captain?

question: You'll get blown outta here some day.
answer: We will never 'evacuate', Captain -- this is our home. Indochina is ours; it has been so for a hundred and twenty-one years, there is something to say for that.

question: The Vietnamese think it's theirs -- I guess the Americans do, too.
answer: But we civilized it. A place belongs to those who bring light to it, don't you agree.

question: We were going upriver when we got caught in a storm, ma'am.
answer: Upriver? Why upriver? There is nothing there, only jungle.

question: Do you know that jungle?
answer: When I was a boy, my father would take me there, to hunt. There are a few savages, but no man can live there, no white man.

question: What about an American named Kurtz?
answer: We have never heard of him. Bon nuit, Roxanne -- bon nuit, Captain.

question: Good night.
answer: You must realize, Captain -- we have lost much here -- I, my husband. Gaston -- his wife and son.

question: I'm sorry to hear that.
answer: Cognac?

question: I should be checking on the boat.
answer: The war will still be here tomorrow.

question: I guess so.
answer: Do you miss your home, Captain? Have you someone there?

question: No. Not really.
answer: Then you are like us. What will you do after the war?

question: I just follow my footsteps, one at a time, trying to answer the little questions and staying away from the big ones.
answer: What's a big question?

question: Kurtz. I know you've heard of him.
answer: Yes.

question: What did you hear?
answer: That strange things.. terrible things have occured around this American, Kurtz.

question: What things?
answer: Gaston would never tell me. It was asubject not to be spoken of, Captain.

question: Yes.
answer: Did you know -- deeper in the jungle, upriver -- there are savages?

question: I know.
answer: But Captain, I mean -- cannibals. What a pity, you don't drink. Since my husband died, there are so many things I must do alone. Are you warm, Captain?

question: The river is beautiful.
answer: I spend hours watching that river from my bedroom window. It fascinates me. I have been lonely here, Captain. I will fix you breakfast.

question: I'm afraid I won't have time -- I gotta --
answer: Whe you reach the boat you will find that half your fifty calibre stores -- a case of grenades, a mortar and two M-16's and a case of clips are being transfered to us by your order.

question: So that's it.
answer: You may think what you wish, Captain, but I like you very much.

question: What if I say no.
answer: Then Philippe will have to kill all of you.

question: No -- leave it --
answer: Why -- Charlie put it there to kill --

question: Thta's not Charlie's work -- Whoever put'em there didn't do it to kill people -- They put 'em up as signs --
answer: Signs?

question: Yeah -- like keep out -- Toward the night of the fifth day out of Do Lung Bridge, we judged ourselves about eight miles from Kurtz' base. Everything was still, the trees, the creepers, even the brush seemed like it had been changed into some kind of stone. It was unnatural, like a trance. Not a sound could be heard. I began to think I was deaf -- then the fog came suddenly, and I was blind too. Listen.
answer: What is it?

question: Listen.
answer: They're on the banks of the river.

question: Shhhhhh. It doesn't sound hostile -- it sounds like they've seen us coming and it sounds like -- I don't know, a funeral. I don't understand. Two hours after the fog lifted, we moved slowly to a spot we thought was roughly a mile and a half below Kurtz's camp. We approached a long sand-bank stretching down the middle of the river.
answer: Which way? Right or left?

question: Who knows? Right.
answer: Looks pretty shallow.

question: Upon reaching objective. Target key personnel and commence operation. Should difficulty arise from which extraction is impossible, break radio silence Com-Sec Command code Strong Arm -- indicate purgative air strike -- code -- Street Gang. Purgative air strike ! Purgative ! They'd kill me too !
answer: Shit ! Fucking arrows ! They're shooting fucking arrows at us.

question: Steer her right. Keep going.. keep going. They're just fucking sticks ! Chief, stay at the helm.
answer: A spear?

question: It was the strangest thing -- I don't know that I can explain it. Two of my men dead, and all I could think of was whether Kurtz was dead too. That's all I wanted Somehow, in the middle of this ... carnival, Kurtz had grown into something -- a gifted officer; a great man. Somehow, he was the only light in this hopeless, hopeless darkness. And now I was too late -- he was probably gone, disappeared... by a grenade rolled into his tent -- or by some spear on the head. Christ, I felt like howling like those animals in the fog. Here they are in Los Angeles. Everything is safe. There's a supermarket around the corner, the police station around the other. It would seem ridiculous to them that I was shot to hell because I had lost the privilege of listening to the mysterious Colonel Kurtz. Of course I was wrong. He was waiting for me. Kurtz was alive and he was waiting for me. Just stand here with me where they can see us. Do nothing. We've been attacked.
answer: Charlie?

question: Looks that way.
answer: Who's he?

question: God knows. Who the hell are you? Moonby what? What is this?
answer: Oh, they're simple enough people. It's good to see you, baby. Nobody has any Winstons? This boat's a mess.

question: Where's Kurtz? I want to talk to him.
answer: Oh, you don't talk to Colonel Kurtz. You listen to him. God, these are good. I kept these people off you, you know. It wasn't easy.

question: Why did they attack us?
answer: Simple. They don't want him to go.

question: You're Australian?
answer: Pre-Australian, actually. But I'd dig goin' to California. I'm California dreamin'.

question: So Kurtz is alive.
answer: Kurtz. I tell you, that man has enlarged my mind. But lemme tell you, he is the most dangerous thing in every way that I've come on so far. He wanted to shoot me. The first thing he said is, 'I'm going to shoot you because you are a deserter.' I said I didn't desert from your army, I deserted from my army. He said, 'I'm going to shoot you just the same.'

question: Why didn't he shoot you?
answer: I've asked myself that question. I said to myself, why didn't he shoot me? He didn't shoot me, because I had a stash like you wouldn't believe. I hid it in the jungle; the wealth of the Orient

question: Oh, no, not what you think... Cosmic love. He made me see things -- things, you know.
answer: Sounds like he's gone crazy.

question: No, Colonel Kurtz couldn't be crazy -- if you heard him talk, just last week, you'd never think he was crazy.
answer: Is that where he is? By the shrunken heads.

question: Those heads, yes. Well, the rebels...
answer: We're going ashore. Tie her up -- and leave your guns up, Lance.

question: Bring your rifles, that's all. Take us to him.
answer: Right on -- he's been waiting for --

question: And shut up. Who are you?
answer: His name is...

question: I'm not ever goin' to tell you to shut up again. What happened here?
answer: What -- happened here.

question: Charlie?
answer: NVA regulars. They're coming again tonight. Tet -- their big -- assault.

question: Colonel Kurtz, I guess.
answer: I'm Kurtz.

question: Captain B.L. Willard reporting his presence, sir.
answer: At ease... Sit down. Why did you come to ... my province.

question: We were attacked -- down river. We need supplies and medical help.
answer: You were not coming here, to see me?

question: No -- no, sir.
answer: You came up my river -- in that small boat. So simple. I always thought the final justice would come from the sky, like we did. You are the final justice, aren't you?

question: What do you mean, Colonel?
answer: What other reason could you have come? A Captain. Ranger. Paratrooper. Graduate of the Recondo School. Am I right about these things?

question: You know you're right.
answer: Then the Agency approached you. Maybe in a bar in Quinon or Pleiku. Simple. A year's pay for one life. Perhaps a village elder, or a tax collector. Nobody's orders but your own. Exciting work. You've spent tome at the Royal Tracking School of Malaysia. I can tell from the way the laces on your boots are tied. I understand you, Captain. We understand each other.

question: Do you know me?
answer: Yes. Do you know me ?

question: Yeah.
answer: He killed that guy without feeling anything.

question: Not a thing.
answer: When you kill Cong, don't you feel something.

question: Sure. Recoil... I feel the recoil of my rifle. This is good -- triple overlapping fields of fire -- walls so thick ordinary artillery just cleans the moss off their surfaces. I've done things, when I was alone in the jungle -- that I never told anyone about.
answer: This is evil -- evil, Captain. We're all gonna die here.

question: Yeah, I know.
answer: I don't get it -- You said your mission was to kill him. Let's do it, an' get our asses outta here. This Kurtz is ruining the war; I mean, this don't look good for America !

question: ... he's an amazing officer.
answer: You got to kill this sonuvabitch -- Lance and me, we don't understand none of this -- Jesus, Captain -- I don't wanna die here -- Do it quick.

question: I'm awake. You. Get out. I said get the fuck out ! I'm going to kill the little weirdo myself tomorrow. Hes only stayed alive this long because he's a good orderly and medic. He knows how to use a hypodermic.
answer: You're gonna get hit tonight, bad -- a whole regiment of NVA regulars.

question: That's right, the little gook- pricks. But they are noble little gook-pricks, noble. Because they fight with their guts, like animals. And for an idea ! That's rich. We fight with ingenious machines and fire, like Gods, and for nothing. But I'll call in a major blotto airstrike tonight. We'll have ourselves a helluva airstrike tonight, a lightshow. How do you like The Doors' Do you?
answer: Yeah, I like it...

question: I love it.
answer: You've gone crazy.

question: Oh shit -- on the table; morphine. You see how stupid it would have been to blow out my brains? I'm dying from the gut anyway. No -- I don't want to sleep. I want to think. Water. Give me water.
answer: You can't have water after morphine.

question: Still playing by the rules. You're a damn good kiler.
answer: How's the pain?

question: How's yours?
answer: I can handle it.

question: Pain is easy to handle -- but nobility.. the nobility of a man is judged by how much Truth he can handle.
answer: What Truth?

question: The truth that you were sent here to murder me, ans so far you haven't done it. And do you know why? Yes, you know why. Your mission makes about as much sense as those idiots who sent you on it. Asshole ! Schmuck ! How long does it take you to figure out that nobody knows what they're doing here. Except me. Gimme water.
answer: No water.

question: Goddamn -- You've gotta dig napalm on Speed, too. It's spectacular, you'll see. Look into the jungle. You can't -- it's too terrible. You have to smear yourself with warpaint to look at it -- you have to be a cannibal. That's why warpaint was invented. Then it becomes your jungle.
answer: How did we get here?

question: Because of all the things we do, the thing we do best -- is lie.
answer: I think think a lie stinks.

question: Oh Captain, that is so true.
answer: Stinks. I could never figure -- I could never figure how they can teach boys how to bomb villages with napalm -- and not let them write the word 'fuck' on their airplanes.

question: You could never figure it because it doesn't make sense.
answer: Fuck no.

question: I'll tell you what makes sense ! Air strikes ! White Phosphorus ! Napalm ! We'll bomb the shit out of them if they don't do what we want.
answer: We'll exterminate the fuckers !

question: Mini-gun. Colby. Sergeant. Mini-gun.
answer: Napalm.

question: Claymores, claymores.
answer: Code -- Street Gang -- Street Gang ! Purgative air strike; Street Gang !

question: Charles ! Go away -- hide yourself.
answer: What are you doing?

question: Going back - to the jungle to die.
answer: I'm taking you back. You can still live.

question: I had immense plans.
answer: I'm gonna get you out of here.

question: He was the tragedy -- the tragedy of this war.
answer: Don't. Don't frighten them away.

question: So you understand this?
answer: Do I not? My river... my people... my jungle... my ideas... my country... my wife... ... my death.

question: You had immense plans... immense plans...
answer: Yes...

question: I'm taking you back.
answer: The horror, the horror.

question: There. How did they know?
answer: They must have seen the fire.

question: They're coming to rescue us. They're Medevac.
answer: They're coming to take us back. Yeah.

question: Colonel Kurtz, he's dead.
answer: Yeah. Yeah. ... Don't remember a lot about my rehabilitation... but I was sent back to the world before the fall of Saigon... I never answered questions about Kurtz -- I gave them a few of his unimportant papers -- but for the most part I saved everything. There were other letters, personal ones written earlier to his wife. I brought them to het. I watched the fall of Saigon on television in a bar in Alameda... Hi.

question: Yeah. Yeah. ... Don't remember a lot about my rehabilitation... but I was sent back to the world before the fall of Saigon... I never answered questions about Kurtz -- I gave them a few of his unimportant papers -- but for the most part I saved everything. There were other letters, personal ones written earlier to his wife. I brought them to het. I watched the fall of Saigon on television in a bar in Alameda... Hi.
answer: Come in, Captain Willard. Can I get anything for you? Did you know him very well?

question: You get to know each other pretty well out there.
answer: And you admired him?

question: He was a remarkable man. It was impossible not to --
answer: Love him... Yes, it is true. That's the hard part for me... I knew him better than anyone ... I knew him best.

question: You knew him best.
answer: You were his friend... You must have been, if he had given you this... If he sent you to his home. He was the best this country had -- he was --

question: Yes, I know...
answer: I'll never get over it -- But I'll always remember him...

question: Both of us...
answer: Men looked up to him... He died as he lived...

question: His death was -- yes, he died as he lived.
answer: Were you with him, when...

question: Yes I was... He said his last words to me.
answer: What were they? Tell me. Tell me what he said.
